Home / Lab 7: Symbolic Algebra

Suggestions for Linear System Solver

You are not logged in.

If you are a current student, please Log In for full access to the web site.
Note that this link will take you to an external site (https://shimmer.mit.edu) to authenticate, and then you will be redirected back to this page.

Another common feature of professional symbolic algebra systems is the ability to solve systems of equations. As the last required piece of this lab, we'll add some of this functionality to our system, in the form of a solver for systems of linear equations.

You could implement this as a function solve_linear_system(equations), where equations is a list of symbolic expressions. This function should return a dictionary mapping variable names (strings) to floating point values representing the values of those variables that are necessary to solve the system.

For the sake of simplicity, we will make some relatively strict assumptions about the form of the equations that are given to the solve_linear_system function. In particular, we will expect that each equation is given as a sum (or difference) of terms, where each term is either a Var, a Num, or a Mul of a Num and a Var; and we will assume that each given expression is equal to zero.

For example, to solve the system of equations given by x+3y=−5x + 3y = -5x+3y=−5 and 4x−3y=104x - 3y = 104x−3y=10, we could do the following to find values for xxx and yyy:

>>> x, y = Var('x'), Var('y')
>>> solve_linear_system([x + 3*y + 5, 4*x - 3*y - 10])
{'x': 1.0, 'y': -2.0}

As we have seen throughout 6.009, the choice of representation for solving a problem can have a big effect on the resulting code, both in terms of how concisely it can be written and in terms of how efficient the code is in the end.

We probably have a good sense of how we can solve systems of linear equations, using something like the substitution method. Consider the problem of finding values for xxx and yyy that satisfy the two equations:

3x+4y=333x + 4y = 333x+4y=33
and
5x−2y=35x - 2y = 35x−2y=3

On paper, you might approach this by solving the second equation for xxx (in terms of yyy), getting x=25y+35x = \frac{2}{5}y + \frac{3}{5}x=52​y+53​, and then substituting that into the first equation, getting the following:

65y+95+4y=33\frac{6}{5}y + \frac{9}{5} + 4y = 3356​y+59​+4y=33

Then, solving for yyy yields y=6y = 6y=6, and substituting y=6y = 6y=6 into the xxx expression tells us that x=3x = 3x=3.

Solving two equations in two unknowns by hand is straightforward, and we could maybe even think about how to replicate that process using our symbolic algebra framework directly. But as we move to more equations in more unknowns, the process gets complicated (both for humans and for our symbolic algebra framework). As such, we're going to suggest using a different approach (and internal representation) for this problem. This does not mean that we should change the existing representation (which works well for the kinds of problems we've seen so far), but that for this part, we might not be making much use of our structures from earlier in the lab.

Again, we could try to write a computer program to perform the substitution method, but this method is complicated and computationally inefficient. By contrast, Gaussian elimination is efficient, and it's also more straightforward to implement on a computer.

1) Gaussian Elimination§

In this section, we will describe the Gaussian Elimination algorithm for solving systems of linear equations. This algorithm works by manipulating systems of linear equations represented as matrix operations.

The example set of linear equations from above can be represented by the following matrix equation:

[345−2][xy]=[333]\left[\begin{array}{cc} 3 & 4\\ 5 & -2\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ y\end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 33\\ 3\end{array}\right][35​4−2​][xy​]=[333​]

The goal of the algorithm is to solve for the middle vector [xy]\left[\begin{array}{c}x\\ y\end{array}\right][xy​].

Generally, we will say that we are solving the equation Ax=bAx = bAx=b, where AAA is a square matrix of coefficients, xxx is a vector of variables (to be solved for), and bbb is a vector containing the solutions to the linear equations.

1.1) Row-echelon Form§

A crucial part of the algorithm is a step called forward elimination, which converts the matrix AAA into row-echelon form. If a matrix is in row-echelon form, that means that reading from left to right, each row will start with at least one more zero term than the row above it.

We can do this by applying the following algorithm (described in pseudocode). Note that, below, we use the notation AijA_{ij}Aij​ to denote the value in row iii and column jjj in matrix AAA, and bib_ibi​ to denote the value in position iii in the vector bbb.

  • For each value ccc between 0 and w−1w-1w−1, inclusive, where www is the number of columns in AAA:
    • Find the row s≥cs\geq cs≥c in AAA whose cthc^\text{th}cth element has the highest magnitude.
      • If AscA_{sc}Asc​ is 0, there is no unique solution to this system (your code should retun None in this case).
      • Otherwise, swap row sss with row ccc in matrix AAA, and swap values sss and ccc in vector bbb.
    • (After the swap described above), for each row j>cj>cj>c, substract off a scaled version of row ccc, scaled by a constant factor xxx chosen so as to make Ajc=0A_{jc} = 0Ajc​=0 (and modify the associated value in bbb accordingly, as well!).

1.2) Back-solving For Variables§

Once the matrix AAA has been converted to row-echelon form, it is possible to back-solve for the values of each of the variables in the vector xxx.

Starting from the bottom row AAA, notice that only one variable has a non-zero coefficient associated with it in that equation. Thus, we can use it (and the corresponding value in bbb) to solve for that variable.

Once we know that variable's value, we can use that, along with the next row from the bottom in AAA, to solve for the next variable. We can repeat this procedure for each row in AAA (from each row, we should be able to determine the value of one more variable).

2) Examples§

Here, we'll walk through a few examples (which could make good test cases for your code, including for any helper functions you write!).

2.1) Example 1§

In this section, we'll work through solving the set of linear equations described above. Our initial setup for that problem was as follows:

[345−2][xy]=[333]\left[\begin{array}{cc} 3 & 4\\ 5 & -2\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ y\end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 33\\ 3\end{array}\right][35​4−2​][xy​]=[333​]

2.1.1) Forward Elimination§

To begin, we look at the first column (i=0i = 0i=0). We look for the row with the highest magnitude value in column 000, and swap it with the current row 000 (both in bbb and in AAA). In this case, we want the row with the leading 555 to be the top row. So after this swap, we have:

[5−234][xy]=[333]\left[\begin{array}{cc} 5 & -2\\ 3 & 4\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ y\end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 3\\ 33\end{array}\right][53​−24​][xy​]=[333​]

(Note that this did not change the system of equations described at all, just the order in which we will consider them). Now, we want to subtract a scaled version of row 000 from row 111 in order to eliminate the value A10A_{10}A10​. The right scaling factor for this is 3/53/53/5.

Subtracting 3/53/53/5 times row 000 from row 111, we have:

[5−23−35(5)4−35(−2)][xy]=[333−35(3)]\left[\begin{array}{cc} 5 & -2\\ 3-\frac{3}{5}\left(5\right) & 4-\frac{3}{5}\left(-2\right)\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ y\end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 3\\ 33-\frac{3}{5}\left(3\right)\end{array}\right][53−53​(5)​−24−53​(−2)​][xy​]=[333−53​(3)​]

Simplifying:

[5−2026/5][xy]=[3156/5]\left[\begin{array}{cc} 5 & -2\\ 0 & 26/5\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ y\end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 3\\ 156/5\end{array}\right][50​−226/5​][xy​]=[3156/5​]

Now we have our matrix in row-echelon form, so we can move on to solving for the variables.

2.1.2) Back-Solving§

We had our system in the following form:

[5−2026/5][xy]=[3156/5]\left[\begin{array}{cc} 5 & -2\\ 0 & 26/5\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ y\end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 3\\ 156/5\end{array}\right][50​−226/5​][xy​]=[3156/5​]

Note that the bottom row represents the equation

265y=1565\frac{26}{5}y = \frac{156}{5}526​y=5156​
Solving, we find that y=6y = 6y=6. Then, the next row up represents the equation 5x−2y=35x -2y = 35x−2y=3. Now that we know yyy, we can solve this equation as well:

5x−2(6)=35x - 2(6) = 35x−2(6)=3

5x=155x = 155x=15

x=3x = 3x=3

So our final solution is

[xy]=[36]\left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ y\end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 3\\ 6\end{array}\right][xy​]=[36​]

2.1.3) Python Form§

In our representation for this lab, we could write code like the following to solve this system:

>>> x, y = Var('x'), Var('y')
>>> eqns = [
...     4*y + 3*x - 33,
...     5*x - 2*y - 3,
... ]
>>> solve_linear_system(eqns)
{'x': 3.0, 'y': 6.0}

2.2) Example 2§

Consider solving the following set of linear equations:

x+3y+7z=18x + 3y + 7z = 18x+3y+7z=18

3x+6y+9z=333x + 6y + 9z = 333x+6y+9z=33

3x+9y+15z=483x + 9y + 15z = 483x+9y+15z=48

In matrix form, this system can be represented as:

[1373693915][xyz]=[183348]\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 3 & 7\\ 3 & 6 & 9\\ 3 & 9 & 15\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ y\\ z\end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 18\\ 33\\ 48\end{array}\right]⎣⎡​133​369​7915​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​xyz​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​183348​⎦⎤​

2.2.1) Forward Elimination§

To begin, we look at the first column (i=0i = 0i=0). We look for the row with the highest magnitude value in column 000, and swap it with the current row 000 (both in bbb and in AAA). In this case, we want either of the rows with the leading 333's to be the top row, so we'll pick the middle one. After swapping row 0 with row 1, we have:

[3691373915][xyz]=[331848]\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 3 & 6 & 9\\ 1 & 3 & 7\\ 3 & 9 & 15\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ y\\ z\end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 33\\ 18\\ 48\end{array}\right]⎣⎡​313​639​9715​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​xyz​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​331848​⎦⎤​

(Note that this did not change the system of equations described at all, just the order in which we will consider them). Now, we want to subtract a scaled version of row 000 from the other rows in order to eliminate the values A10A_{10}A10​ and A20A_{20}A20​.

To do this, we need to subtract 1/31/31/3 times row 000 from row 111, and 111 times row 000 from row 222.

After this subtraction, we have:

[369014036][xyz]=[33715]\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 3 & 6 & 9\\ 0 & 1 & 4\\ 0 & 3 & 6\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ y\\ z\end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 33\\ 7\\ 15\end{array}\right]⎣⎡​300​613​946​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​xyz​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​33715​⎦⎤​

From here on out, row 000 will remain unchanged.

Now we are moving on to the second column (i=1i=1i=1). Again, if there is a row below this one that has a higher magnitude value in column 111, we want to swap those two rows in the matrix. In this case, the bottom row has value 333 in column 111, so we want to swap it with row 111. After swapping rows 1 and 2, we have:

[369036014][xyz]=[33157]\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 3 & 6 & 9\\ 0 & 3 & 6\\ 0 & 1 & 4\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ y\\ z\end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 33\\ 15\\ 7\end{array}\right]⎣⎡​300​631​964​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​xyz​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​33157​⎦⎤​

Now we need to eliminate column 2 from all rows below this one. We can do this by subtracting 1/31/31/3 times row 1 from row 2:

[369036002][xyz]=[33152]\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 3 & 6 & 9\\ 0 & 3 & 6\\ 0 & 0 & 2\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ y\\ z\end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 33\\ 15\\ 2\end{array}\right]⎣⎡​300​630​962​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​xyz​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​33152​⎦⎤​

Now we have our matrix in row-echelon form, so we can move on to solving for the variables.

2.2.2) Back-Solving§

We had our system in the following form:

[369036002][xyz]=[33152]\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 3 & 6 & 9\\ 0 & 3 & 6\\ 0 & 0 & 2\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ y\\ z\end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 33\\ 15\\ 2\end{array}\right]⎣⎡​300​630​962​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​xyz​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​33152​⎦⎤​

Note that the bottom row represents the equation

2z=22z = 22z=2
Solving, we find that z=1z = 1z=1. Then, the next row up represents the equation 3y+2z=153y + 2z = 153y+2z=15. Now that we know zzz, we can solve this equation as well:

3y+6(1)=153y + 6(1) = 153y+6(1)=15

3y=93y = 93y=9

y=3y = 3y=3

And our final equation is 3z+6y+9z=333z+6y+9z = 333z+6y+9z=33. Knowing values for yyy znd zzz, we can solve for xxx:

3x+6(3)+9(1)=333x + 6(3) + 9(1) = 333x+6(3)+9(1)=33

3x=63x = 63x=6

x=2x = 2x=2

So our final solution is

[xyz]=[231]\left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ y\\ z\end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 2\\ 3\\ 1\end{array}\right]⎣⎡​xyz​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​231​⎦⎤​

2.2.3) Python Form§

In our representation for this lab, we could write code like the following to solve this system:

>>> x, y, z = Var('x'), Var('y'), Var('z')
>>> eqns = [
...     x + 3*y + 7*z - 18,
...     3*x + 6*y + 9*z - 33,
...     3*x + 9*y + 15*z - 48,
... ]
>>> solve_linear_system(eqns)
{'x': 2.0, 'y': 3.0, 'z': 1.0}
